ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Writing a research proposal, writing an IRB, basic lab skills
I have learned a lot about scientific writing principles and research design.
This class is made to help learn how to conduct research and write about it! I am learning how to independently devote time to research and stay on top of my work throughout the semester.
research skills

This course is incredibly freedom and wholly dependent on your advisor, so it is difficult to generalize. I personally received assistance with the data analysis portion of my thesis, having finished the collection over the summer.
I learned a lot of microbiology laboratory techniques such as picking and streaking colonies, growing colonies in media, serotyping, etc.

Research is difficult!! 
It was challenging to keep my project organized amidst many different challenges and setbacks. However, it was very satisfying to complete a finished report. I also gained lots of skills in terms of using R and organizing and executing a research project.
How to manage a 10hr/week independent research schedule. Summarizing preliminary goals, plans, and findings.
I learned a lot of basic research skills, especially troubleshooting experiments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: lots of freedom 
weaknesses: could have a few more checkpoints within the semester to hold students accountable

Weakness: maybe a bi weekly meeting with others writing their thesis could be helpful to discuss difficulties.
Strength; help from my advisor was very useful.
There is not much direction on when things need to be done by.  However, the purpose of this class is to make students independently learn how to devote their time to research!
it is just independent research - i had a good experience in my lab. the requirements are a proposal and a progress report, which are both very doable and help to structure the semester
Again, totally up to you. My personal advice is to meet relatively frequently with your advisor in order to get the most out of your thesis.
I like that the course is very independent and we were allowed to come up with our own project and our own timeline for how we will complete everything.
A strength was that it was really educational. A weakness is that it was hard to self-motivate. I don't know how to address that.

Perhaps a little more guidance (even if just a handout at the beginning of the semester) of some tips and recommendations for students conducting research for 10 hours a week, especially if it's their first research experience. Might be hard given the diversity of projects, but one quickly gets used to the independence and work ethic!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, necessary for EEB graduation and prepares you well for future research in the field.
I would since you have to take it. I would advise the full year if you are doing lab work.
Yes, if you need to do an E&EB B.S. senior research requirement!
if you are taking it, you have to because you are an E&EB senior doing it to fulfill your major requirements. it's not bad though if you have a good lab.
Its required, so you know how it goes.

Yes, although it is a requirement to graduate for seniors, I still like the freedom and independence that this kind of course brings. It is also fun to be applying what we have been learning inside a lab rather than sit in class.
Yes! I learned a lot.

I personally enjoy the independence of research, and I think it's a very worthwhile experience for those willing to do some wetlab work and/or data analysis. The 10 hours/week average helps pace your project, but don't treat the course like it's a "real" 1-credit, treat it more like two 0.5-credit science labs (plus a couple more hours!). I recommend starting research at least the summer beforehand.
